Navigation
Name Rascal/Expressions/Values/Set/Union
Synopsis Union of two set values.
Syntax Exp1 + Exp2
Types
Exp1 Exp2 Exp1 + Exp2
set[T1] set[T2] set[lub(T1,T2)]
Description The + operator computes set union if both operands are sets. If one of the operands is not a set, it acts as Set/Insert instead.
Examples 
rascal>{1, 2, 3} + {4, 5, 6};
set[int]: {6,5,4,3,2,1}
rascal>{1,2,3} + {2,3,4};
set[int]: {4,3,2,1}
rascal>{1, 2, 3} + {3};
set[int]: {3,2,1}
rascal>{2} + { 2, 3, 4};
set[int]: {4,3,2}

Questions
Question [1]. When you compute the union of two sets, the number of elements in the result is always:




Question [2].
The type of {"Pineapple", "Lavender", "Ailyn Vel", "Countess Von Backwards"} + {"K", "Sesame", "U", "W", "A"} is

Question [3]. 
{10.24610512051450400, -1.848277546461578800, 18.91718470005936400} + {-6.153593527879350800, 8.6778651684047600, -2.685944035362846000, 4.71447265865039600, -1.27818821817546400} ==

Question [4]. 
{2} +  == {-1,-4,6,2}

Question [5]. 
{15} + {18, -17, 17} ==

Question [6]. 
{"Anakin Skywalker"} + {} ==
